Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES DDLP: Aligning for Impact: Computer Science Pathways Across Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Aligning for Impact: Computer Science Pathways Across Contexts [CS-PAC] is an NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilot. It broadens participation of students who are underrepresented in computer science by using the convening and policy-making power of the Georgia State Department of Education to coalesce school district leaders to implement K-12 computer science education. The project provides a national model for how to work toward systemic change. With the State Department of Education's coordination, several school districts will collaboratively seek improvements in their own student participation rates. The coordination of data reporting and analysis, resources, communications, and policy promote more equitable participation in computer science education. Research emerging from this project informs other states about how to collaboratively shape computer science education policy and policy implementation.

Using a Collective Impact approach to systemic change, the project creates sustainable institutional change at the community, state, and national levels. Qualitative and quantitative data provide descriptions about how to utilize alignment strategies within Collective Impact in three different contexts: rural, suburban, and urban. Outcomes utilize a regression discontinuity analysis to justify successful implementation as well as qualitative analysis of implementation efforts that were deemed most effective by all stakeholders. The project outputs directly affect over 88,000 students across five districts and indirectly affect over 1.7 million in Georgia alone. The culminating project goal is the development of a coherent framework for aligning K-12 computer science education pathways.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Georgia Department of Education and the CS4GA Collective are working to broaden participation in Computer Science education in Georgia. After working to develop an overall plan of address, CS4GA settled on teachers and districts as the major touchpoints of influence. Several CS4GA members are PD providers and work with teachers regularly so this project was developed to address district readiness to implement K-12 Computer Science education. The goals of the project were to identify the challenges or barriers to implementing CS in three distinctly different contexts: urban, suburban, and rural school districts, and support districts in the development of interventions for overcoming those challenges. The collective could then share the lessons learned with other districts in Georgia as the state embarked on this transformative process. 

Background/context. Georgia has 213 local education agencies and the Aligning for Impact grant engaged 5 of these LEAs. The project worked with one cluster each in three rural school districts: Ben Hill, Brooks, and Thomas County districts; two clusters in one suburban school district: Douglas County; and one cluster in one urban district: Atlanta Public Schools. The goals of the plan were four fold. 

  1. Align data between state and local systems to create a shared measurement system. 
  2. Align resources from community, state, and national sources
  3. Align efforts between state actors, local school stakeholders, and community (out-of-school) stakeholders
  4. Address equity issues through these alignments

The initial project convening of the five districts was a SCRIPT training in Atlanta. The SCRIPT tool was created by the CSforAll Consortium to help districts develop a CS implementation plan. The districts were asked to do a landscape report to create a baseline of where each district was regarding CS education prior to the training. This landscape report would be used periodically over the course of the project. The SCRIPT process recommends that each district bring a diverse team of stakeholders to participate in the training and each district complied with strong participation. The training lasted a day and a half and additionally served as an opportunity for the project team to orient the districts with project expectations, goals, and timelines. Over the course of the SCRIPT training, districts developed an implementation plan with specific focus placed on key areas identified by the tool: CS education vision, implementation team, building teacher capacity, choosing CS equipment and curriculum, and developing partnerships. CS4GA has since added an attention to equity to subsequent SCRIPT trainings due to the lessons learned over the course of this project.

Following the SCRIPT introduction, a liaison was identified to serve as a CS engagement specialist for the southern, rural districts and one of the project administrators served in this role for the urban and suburban districts. Over the course of the two years of the project, the specialists organized various meetings with the district teams to explore the alignment and efficient use of district resources, stakeholders, and to follow up on the action items identified as part of the districts’ implementation plan. These meetings routinely included data visualizations provided by the state CS specialist tailored to each district. District teams would look over their initial barriers and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions while also strengthening their infrastructure to create a systematic approach to implementing CS education that would be sustainable. 

The A4I project has resulted in several outcomes that are beneficial to the pilot districts, the state of Georgia, and the CS education community at large. The first, and most salient, is the benefit of a comprehensive plan for implementing structural change that will positively impact student CS opportunities sustainably. The SCRIPT tool was customized for the Georgia context and the specific contexts of the pilot districts. It would be difficult to assess the long term impact of lasting structures that were built in conjunction with and parallel to this project but early enrollment numbers, especially among marginalized populations, are encouraging. All five districts found vertical alignment meetings invaluable and by aligning their efforts with state initiatives were able to secure additional funding for their CS programs. All districts increased the number of trained and credentialed CS teachers and each district sent a representative to share at the recent state CS summit, hosting the next cohort of 8 districts beginning the process. The A4I team developed a public data dashboard and a district toolkit that other districts around the state can take advantage of as they join the movement to offer CS to all students in the state. The GaDOE and CS4GA is already making plans to repeat this process with a third and fourth cohort of districts as the process is continually refined and codified for sustainable use in CS education implementation.
